stories.name: Living Without an ID: Why It Happens

content.title: Living Without an ID: Why It Happens
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: Why is something so basic as an ID still out of reach for so many? And how do we make sure identification rules don’t end up excluding the very people they’re supposed to support?

stories.name: What 25 Differing Countries Show Us About Ending Poverty

content.title: What 25 Differing Countries Show Us About Ending Poverty
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: 25 countries have halved multidimensional poverty within 15 years. That kind of progress is rare, and it matters.

content.title: How Country Offices Work
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: We keep the core structure of Social Income country offices the same everywhere we operate. This consistency ensures our work is transparent, reliable, and trustworthy.

content.title: We Wouldn’t Exist Without Support From the Arts. It’s that simple.
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: Social Income did not begin as an art project, but it did begin within the arts. Our first recipients were young struggling artists in Sierra Leone who faced financial pressure.

content.title: Why U.S. Aid Cuts May Mark a Turning Point for Global Development
content.author: 05d3aabd-75bc-4417-b6f1-1abc488f5acc
content.leadText: The collapse of USAid has shaken the aid world. It also raises an uncomfortable question: Is it time to trust local people?

content.text: This journal post was last updated on January 5, 2025 by Matthew Roberts.

content.title: Where Do We Expand Next?
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: We’re often asked why we aren’t active in more countries yet. The answer is multilayered, and it begins with one person taking the first step.

content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: All beginnings involve some admin. It’s not the most exciting part, but it lays the foundation for good practice, data protection, and smooth collaboration. Let’s get it done.

content.title: Traveling to Guinea.
content.author: 7da3f4b9-1176-47f5-acc6-ae15f90e35f5
content.leadText: Have you ever visited Guinea? If not, it definitely belongs on your list. Whether you fly in or take the overland route, you’re met with a journey full of contrast and character.
content.subtitle: A guide for travelers who go further

content.title: Traveling to Sierra Leone.
content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: Yes, you should visit Sierra Leone. That’s the simple answer if you’re asking yourself whether it's worth the trip. It’s the kind of experience that stays with you.

content.text: This journal post was last updated on November 17, 2025 by Jessica Freeman, Kerrin Dieckmann, and Sandino Scheidegger.

content.title: Why Global Cash Transfers Matter.
content.author: 7da3f4b9-1176-47f5-acc6-ae15f90e35f5
content.leadText: The Swiss newspaper NZZ proposes a radical idea: a global basic income for the world's poorest people. The reasoning is pragmatic and highly compelling.

content.title: It’s not that hard.
content.author: f9a6d2d9-4328-434f-8005-d88df53079e1
content.leadText: Last month, Marc and I went on the biggest adventure of our lives – at least so far. We boarded a flight to Monrovia to help set up a new cash transfer program in Liberia, part of Social Income’s effort to reach more people in West Africa who are living in poverty.
content.subtitle: Here are the basics of basic income.

content.title: Tech for Good: Why Open Source Matters in the Fight for Equality
content.author: 9ff51718-38b3-4f7f-8dad-f5181839b679
content.leadText: What happens when financial justice meets open source technology? Learn how Social Income is using transparent, collaborative tools to build a fairer world.

content.title: Why People Leave .
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: In a recent interview, ETH Zurich researcher Jan Freihardt challenged a familiar narrative: that people in the Global South are fleeing their homes en masse toward the Global North due to climate change. It’s an interesting perspective—and one that made me pause.
content.subtitle: And How Cash Lets Them Stay

image.alt: Workers loading long wooden logs onto a truck in a busy street with buildings and power lines in the background.

meta_data.alt: Workers loading long wooden logs onto a truck in a busy street with buildings and power lines in the background.

content.title: UBI Without Borders.
content.author: 759659f7-f3be-4b63-bbd7-f8a4aa6ac43c
content.leadText: In 2016, Swiss voters overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to implement an unconditional basic income (UBI) for all. While the idea sparked global conversation, skepticism lingered — especially around one persistent concern: affordability.
content.subtitle: Social Income as a Model of Transnational Solidarity in a Fragmenting World

content.text: Bertelsmann Stiftung, BTI 2022 Country Report – Sierra Leone. Gütersloh: Bertelsmann Stiftung, 2022.

The international $ (Int$) is a hypothetical currency tied to the purchasing power parity (PPP) of the US$ in the United States at any given time. Taking into account inflation rates, the effective amount paid out by Social Income in the local currency is subject to change. By time of writing, the monthly installments were each 700 SLE.

stories.name: Remembering the Ebola Crisis in Sierra Leone: A Story of Resilience

image.alt: Ismatu Mariatu and the Sierra Leone Association of Ebola Survivors in Kenema

meta_data.alt: Ismatu Mariatu and the Sierra Leone Association of Ebola Survivors in Kenema

content.title: Remembering the Ebola Crisis in Sierra Leone.
content.author: 9ff51718-38b3-4f7f-8dad-f5181839b679
content.leadText: When Ebola swept through Sierra Leone, it left behind more than just loss: it tested the strength of an entire nation. We look back at the crisis, the courage of survivors, and how a community rose from tragedy to rebuild, resist stigma, and reclaim hope.
content.subtitle: A Story of Resilience

content.title: Microcredits Sound Great.
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: Microcredits are meant to fight poverty. For the poorest, however, they often create more pressure than opportunity.

stories.name: The Real Power of Influencers in Ending Poverty

image.alt: Dancer performing in abandoned building in Freetown

meta_data.alt: Dancer performing in abandoned building in Freetown

content.title: From Clicks to Change: The Real Power of Influencers in Ending Poverty
content.author: 9ff51718-38b3-4f7f-8dad-f5181839b679
content.leadText: In a world where one Instagram Story can reach thousands and a single TikTok can go viral overnight, influencers hold a kind of digital megaphone that brands use to pay millions for. But beyond product launches and sponsored content, there’s a growing movement where this influence is being used for something far more powerful: social change. When it comes to fighting poverty, influencers can be game-changers.

image.alt: Riccardo standing next to SLAES in Kenema with his camera

meta_data.alt: Riccardo standing next to SLAES in Kenema with his camera

content.title: Chocolate, Filmmaking & Basic Income:
content.author: 9ff51718-38b3-4f7f-8dad-f5181839b679
content.leadText: It started with a Wikipedia page that vanished as quickly as I found it. That moment led me to Social Income. Four years later, I share how it shaped my journey.
content.subtitle: My Journey with Social Income to Fight Inequality

stories.name: 1% — Because Doing Something Beats Doing Nothing

image.alt: Sierra Leone Scene

content.title: 1% — Because Doing Something Beats Doing Nothing
content.author: 1dc9edb3-8741-413f-a86f-4c2dade51c83
content.leadText: We know we could do more. We read headlines about hunger, poverty, and deep inequality. We hear staggering numbers—millions living on less than two dollars a day. Even a small contribution from us can meaningfully improve someone’s life. Yet, we pause. Not from lack of caring, but from uncertainty: Where do we start? Will our contribution really matter? Too often, hesitation becomes our way of quieting the guilt of doing nothing.

image.alt: Sierra Leone Street Scene

content.title: How to Reduce Income Inequality?
content.author: 05d3aabd-75bc-4417-b6f1-1abc488f5acc
content.leadText: Direct cash transfers can be an effective tool for reducing income inequality because they provide financial support to those who are struggling to make ends meet.

image.alt: Mobile Money Freetown

content.title: What is Poverty?
content.author: 9ff51718-38b3-4f7f-8dad-f5181839b679
content.leadText: Poverty is a major global issue that affects billions of people around the world.

image.alt: Sierra Leone Street Scene

content.title: Fighting Global Poverty with the Help of Everyday People
content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: Social Income lets everyone participate in the fight against global poverty by contributing 1% of their income, which is paid out directly to the phones of people in need. Their approach builds on a reliable, preexisting direct cash donation system, which has proven to be both effective and scalable. The only requirement is a cell phone capable of mobile banking, which makes Sierra Leone—a fast-growing mobile money market—a perfect location.

image.alt: Flag Sierra Leone

content.title: World Poverty Statistics 2024
content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: Facing the harsh reality of extreme poverty, over 700 million individuals globally survive on under $1.90 per day, a crisis that disproportionately affects children. The goal to eradicate this by 2030 underlines the vital global effort of Sustainable Development Goal 1.

stories.name: A Will and a Way to End Poverty

image.alt: Kids in Sierra Leone

content.title: A Will and a Way to End Poverty
content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: The Swiss nonprofit Social Income asks, “What would change if you gave away 1% of your income every month? Not much, right?”

image.alt: Broken Chair

content.title: One Percent is Actually Ridiculous
content.author: 3c8b8946-23c5-4b96-a737-a39733c5ab58
content.leadText: The Zurich-based project Social Income provides people in Sierra Leone with an unconditional basic income. Could this be the future of poverty alleviation?
